text: 4. We consider the differential equation yy” + (y')2 = 0 for ¢ > 0. We know that y1(t) = t'/? and y2(t) = 1 are solutions to this equation. (a) Show that y(t) = Ciy1(t) + Caya(t), with C1,Cs € R, is not, in general, a solution to this equation. (b) Explain why the previous result doesn’t contradict the principle of superposition.
